Award.AwardTitle: Science and Mathematics Teacher Research Initiative: a Comparative Study of CalTeach Students to non-CalTeach Students in the Same Teacher Preparation Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the 2010 National Research Council's report, "Preparing Teachers: Building Evidence for Sound Policy," areas related to STEM teacher preparation that lacked a sufficient research base were highlighted. This Noyce Track 4B research project, The Science and Mathematics Teacher Research Initiative (SMTRI), seeks to conduct a research study focusing on secondary STEM teacher preparation at five University of California's campuses: UC Berkeley (UCB), UC Davis (UCD), UC Santa Barbara (UCSB), UC Santa Cruz (UCSC), and UC San Diego (UCSD). This project focuses on a critical challenge in STEM education: preparing novice secondary school teachers to provide effective science and mathematics instruction to the increasingly culturally and linguistically diverse secondary school population who have traditionally been underserved in STEM education and are underrepresented in STEM degrees and careers. The study will analyze the impact of the University of California Undergraduate CalTeach program, which provides undergraduate STEM majors with STEM education coursework and field practicum, on the development of novice teachers' knowledge, beliefs and practice as they progress through their program of pre-service teacher preparation into the first year of teaching. This will be done through a comparative study of CalTeach students to non-CalTeach students in the same teacher preparation programs. The study will also track the participants through the first year of teaching to analyze school placement, retention and teaching efficacy of the two groups. The research will include an emphasis on the preparation of teachers to implement the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and Common Core State Standards (CSSS-Mathematics) and the related challenge of integrating the teaching of academic language and literacy into the teaching of STEM subjects for English Learners (EL).

The SMTRI research study will conduct three analyses to investigate: (1) the impact of undergraduate STEM Education on STEM graduates' decision to become teachers -- who they are and what they do after graduation; (2) the development of CalTeach program graduates' knowledge, beliefs and practice for teaching mathematics and science in comparison with the development of non-CalTeach graduates as they progress through teacher preparation into their first year of teaching; and (3) the impact of the form of the teacher preparation program by comparing novice teacher development in an undergraduate teacher education program at UCB with the development of novice teachers in traditional graduate programs of teacher education at UCD, UCSB, UCSC and UCSD. The STEM focus for this proposal is secondary STEM teacher education (certification areas: biology, chemistry, mathematics and biology). The SMTRI project also will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups by improving the knowledge base on preparing all teachers to work with culturally and linguistically diverse student populations. The project will develop a research and development partnership among five university teacher education programs (UCB, UCD, UCSB, UCSC, UCSD) with the possibility of scaling up to similar teacher education programs nationally. Ultimately, SMTRI has the potential to make a significant contribution to research on STEM education, teacher education, and EL learning as it examines STEM teacher preparation and the integration of science, language and literacy teaching in the NGSS and CCSS. The findings of this study have the potential for wide scale impact in an area of professional education where many teacher education programs are weak in preparing student teachers to implement standards-based science and mathematics teaching in culturally and linguistically diverse classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Science and Mathematics Teacher Research Initiative (SMTRI) was a multi-university study of science and mathematics teacher preparation. Researchers from six University of California (UC) campuses collaborated with the goal of understanding how to better prepare science and mathematics teachers to teach current standards in culturally and linguistically diverse classrooms. Over four years, SMTRI collected survey, interview, and teacher performance assessment (i.e., edTPA) data from 180 preservice teachers (commonly known as "student teachers") enrolled in six teacher education programs (TEPs), with follow-up data from 60 of these teachers during their first years of teaching. Five TEPs were post-baccalaureate programs, which are typical in California, and one was a unique undergraduate TEP. SMTRI also collected survey data from 468 undergraduates enrolled in CalTeach -- a UC-wide initiative to recruit and prepare STEM undergraduates for teaching careers. Several analyses using our extensive data set have yielded insight on how various forms of teacher preparation shape what beginning teachers know and do.

In an analysis of CalTeach survey data, we found that CalTeach helped solidify participants' decisions to pursue teaching as career, and that classroom-based field experiences were particularly influential in shaping their decisions. We also found that CalTeach helped some participants decide not to pursue teaching: They learned that teaching was not aligned with their strengths or interests. Additionally, we found that most participants reported gaining knowledge of educational issues and standards from CalTeach; fewer reported gaining an understanding of multilingual learners (MLs).

In an analysis of preservice teacher survey data, we examined the effects of teacher preparation on three dimensions of teacher readiness: (1) teachers' understanding of how to implement current standards, (2) their understanding of how to teach MLs, and (3) their beliefs about their abilities and skills as educators. We found that CalTeach was associated with developing teachers' understanding of standards-based instruction but was not associated with the other two dimensions. We also found that the post-baccalaureate TEPs were effective in developing preservice teachers' understanding of ML instruction, whereas the undergraduate TEP was not.

In an analysis of interview data, we examined preservice teachers' sense of preparation for and understanding of instruction for MLs. We found that participants from the undergraduate TEP reported lower levels of preparation than participants from the post-baccalaureate TEPs. However, across TEPs, participants identified placements in classrooms with linguistically and culturally diverse students and coursework addressing MLs as the two most important factors contributing to their preparation. We also found that participants emphasized the instructional principle of supporting disciplinary language and largely neglected the principle of engaging MLs in scientific or mathematical practices (see Figure).

In another analysis of interview data, we examined preservice science teachers' understanding of the eight science and engineering practices (SEPs) highlighted in current standards. We found that, over time, participants more often discussed using multiple SEPs together in coordinated ways. However, they consistently reported struggling with two SEPs: developing and using models and using mathematics and computational thinking. We also examined how participants discussed SEPs in intersection with three principles of instruction for culturally and linguistically diverse students (see again Figure). We found that participants focused more often on language production and language support related to SEPs than on student funds of knowledge. Participants most frequently discussed the SEP of engaging in argument from evidence in intersection with these principles. Findings were consistent across TEPs.

In an analysis of interview and edTPA data, we examined preservice mathematics teachers' understanding of the eight mathematical practices from current standards. We found that participants overwhelmingly considered the two practices of make sense of problems and persevere in solving them and construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others to be the most important to teach. Participants also identified the practices of model with mathematics and look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning as the ones they needed further support to understand. Additionally, we found that participants' use of mathematical practices in their edTPA lessons strongly correlated with their edTPA scores. Findings were again consistent across TEPs.

SMTRI's findings contribute to the knowledge base on science and mathematics teacher preparation and indicate ways to strengthen programs. Our findings suggest that undergraduate STEM teacher recruitment programs, such as CalTeach, can help undergraduates decide to pursue teaching; however, to better prepare undergraduates for teaching, these recruitment programs should address both standards-based instruction and instruction for MLs. Our findings also point to common strengths and areas of improvement across TEPs. For example, participants across programs reported challenges with the same scientific or mathematical practices. Further, we found some differences among TEPs, notably between the undergraduate TEP and the post-baccalaureate ones. There are many factors that could contribute to these differences, and our study prompts the need for further investigation to tease apart the strengths and limitations of undergraduate versus post-baccalaureate TEPs.
